Review: Worth playing if you want the full FFVII story, especially if you enjoy the games as much as I do. However, there are some issues with the game that I really didn't like, those mainly being the difficulty of the game and side missions. If you want a fun and challenging experience, playing it on hard is the way to go, but if you don't like playing/grinding through the ton of boring and very linear/simple side quests then you are in trouble. You can get away with skipping all or most of them till around chapter 4 but after that, some of the enemies, and definitely the bosses, start getting pretty tough till you're basically getting one shotted. Because I really didn't want to grind through these side missions (aside from a select few that granted me summons or shops) I decided to switch to normal mode in game options, which is when I ran into my next issue with difficulty which was that normal mode felt like easy mode. It got to the point where I could sometimes be looking away from the screen in combat scenarios, spam spells and be done with a fight in seconds. Most of the rest of the game was like this except for a few tough enemies and the bosses (which aside from the final boss were also quite easy). So would I still recommend this game? Yes, but only to people who really like this series and want to get the full story experience. And even with that, I would say wait to get it on sale like I did.

Review: Pros: - One of my favorite maps in the series. - Gameplay is relatively fun if you're a fan of the series and don't mind the fact that it's basically more of the same thing again. Cons: - If you're expecting something totally new and revolutionary then don't even bother, because this feels like all the other Far Cry's all over again. - The constant helicopters/reinforcements that are oftentimes called down on you when you are detected in bases gets REAL old, real quick. On top of that, they seem to arrive pretty quickly after detection, like seconds after you're detected in some cases. - Normal mode is really easy, especially if you play it coop. If you are experienced in playing FPS games, I'd suggest playing on hard, especially if you plan on playing it coop, and maybe that might even be too easy if you play it coop depending your skill levels. So far, playing it on hard mode, solo is pretty challenging for me. - One of the most woke and cringey games I've ever played, to the point where I sometimes just skip over entire cinematics or mute the obnoxious dialogue. This is especially true of what is one of the most obnoxious factions in the game, the Maximas Matanzas. An extremely cringey group of gen Z guerrilla fighters who are running a revolutionary radio station. Honestly, they have some of the most annoying dialogue I've ever heard in a video game. Also, the beginning of the game is filled with annoying lines of how the "Yanquis" (Americans) are racist and the American dream is only for them.  Finally there was a small symbol of a man's face that I saw when you are sending your guerrilla fighters out on small missions, that clearly is supposed to be like an outline of Che Guevarra. A brutal leader in the communist Cuban revolution, who also happened to be an actual racist and homophobe. Honestly, (as a Cuban myself) it's disgusting that someone this evil would be referenced as a symbol on a team you're fighting for, as if he was the face of goodness and freedom in revolutions. - I tried the dlc's out a while back when I had the Ubisoft subscription and honestly after finishing all 3 (not including Lost Between Worlds) they were not worth the time invested imo. I was bored as hell by the end of them. Verdict: If you want some mindless gaming junk food and enjoy Far Cry games like myself, then you'll probably enjoy it. If not then definitely skip this one. My score: 6/10

Review: I am very disappointed by this "Definitive Edition". Many issues exist across the whole trilogy: many character models look bad and cartoony, some bugs remain, much of the gore/dismemberment was removed, Confederate flags were removed, some songs were removed from radio stations, and certain voice lines from cut scenes from the original PS2 releases were left cut rather than inserting these scenes back in the way the game was originally intended to be released. I think it's ridiculous that Rockstar is now concerned with not offending people when this whole series became popular and made them millions due to it's gritty and offensive nature. Censorship destroys art and NEVER improves it. If you can't handle this kind of content then go play something else, this was rated M for a reason. Now I'm not going to sit here and lie to you and say I'm not enjoying myself, because the core of these games is still here and these are some of my favorite games of all time. Also, a few character models here and there look good/decent and so do some of the graphical improvements. And I am enjoying the fact that achievements were added along with checkpoints (which help in some of the longer/more frustrating missions). But if you don't care about these additions and have the ability to play the original versions then I would suggest you go ahead skip this edition. This is not a definitive edition, this is a joke and a cash grab. My score: 5/10

But even on these settings, the game looked great and the frame rate was always really smooth and stayed above 60 fps. Negatives: - Price: $50 for what is essentially a dlc with a story that you can complete in about 6 hours is ridiculous imo. If you do all the side quests and a bunch of the side activities you can get more time out of it, but at most I would pay $25 for this. By the time I had reached 94% completion I was pretty burned out and done with this game. - Story: Story wise, it was just ok, I wasn't really impressed. And there was a woke vibe running through the game, which though not too in your face was definitely present and annoying if you pay attention. -Enemies: Some of the characters and the main antagonists were where this game really fell apart and ruined a big part of the experience for me. A large chunk of the enemies were actually decent imo and I thought the intro with Rhino was actually pretty cool, but "The Underground" faction of enemies and their leader sucked and they are supposed to be the main antagonists of the game. I really didn't enjoy playing a large part of the game fighting really lame looking neon purple Gen Z cyberpunk kids. None of them, except for the heavy shield enemies, look remotely intimidating, but instead look like a bunch of angry college kids in futuristic neon purple outfits. And as for their leader the Tinkerer, I hated this character just as much, since she was just as lame as the rest of her crew. - Characters: Most were decent and some I actually liked, such as Miles' uncle. But when it came to your best friend Ganke and the main character himself, Miles Morales, I could not stand them and I hated most of their sense of humor. Miles I found to be particularly annoying especially due to his high pitched, whiny voice acting. Am I playing as a 17 year old or an obnoxious little kid with a high pitched voice? When your main characters and antagonists are this bad, that is a big issue. Verdict: This game is not bad, but it's not great either. Obviously I'm in the minority here so you may really like it because it does have some good things going for it, but some of these characters and enemies just didn't do it for me at all. My score: 6/10

Review: After reading all the positive reviews and seeing what looked like very promising games, I was really excited to play this. However, it was a very lackluster collection, that I cannot recommend at full price. I feel bad saying this, as I know these devs must have put a lot of hard work and love into these games, but I just can't recommend this. 1. Hub world: Oh god this was a drag. Your character slowly walks around the map (no sprint available) accomplishing the various boring objectives. There is no action or enemies, at least from what I saw because it was so boring I couldn't even make myself finish the final portion of it (the portion that unlocks once you have completed the other games). To make it all worse, the story was uninteresting and the character Artemis, had some of the worst voice acting and dialogue I've encountered in a while. I don't mean to sound over the top, but it was literally that bad. 2. Axis Mundi: It tried to go for a Fatal Frame feel, with the ghosts and having a camera as a weapon, but failed to be fun, interesting, or scary. The level and enemy design (only 2 main enemies and one boss) was very lack luster as well. 3. Seraphixial: Probably the worst of the collection. Bland graphics and enemy/level design, along with very boring game play. I'm surprised I finished it tbh. 4. Rose of Meat: I gotta say, I loved so many aspects of this game as it was just absolutely bizarre, which is a huge plus for me. However, just personally, I did not enjoy the game play and parts of the map just felt way too cluttered with the many random objects and enemies/NPC's in the game. Many people are either going to love this one or hate it, I fall somewhere in the middle. 5. Black Relic: I loved the theme and graphics in this one, but the colors were much too muddled at times. It became an eye sore after a while and made navigating the map difficult at times. The game play was just ok, and there were only two enemy types, aside from the boss. 6. The Fruit: Ok story, ok gameplay and ok look/feel to the game. Some may like this, but I was personally left feeling very meh when I completed it. 7. The House of Unrest: The story in this one was cool and I liked the look and vibe it had, for the most part. However, the gun play was very simple and boring, and you use what feels like a toy pistol for almost the entire game and only get to use an AK at the end. A shame because it was actually a fun weapon to use, even if it was OP. Also, there is only one (very bland) main enemy type, a second tougher enemy type that you barely get to fight and the boss. The final boss/arena was actually pretty cool, but it was so easy I finished it in one try within 30 seconds. 8. Uktena 64: Finally, this one was actually fun and worth my time, definitely my favorite. Good humor, cool story, and I liked the level/enemy design and graphics. The quality of this one was overall the best in the collection, but I am not surprised because the dev for this one was Kira, the same person who made Lost in Vivo (a must play for any retro horror fan). Obviously not as good as Lost in Vivo, but it was definitely fun for a short game.

Review: This game has a lot potential. The theme is great, monsters are cool, and combat is fun. However it is considerably less fun than it can be, because of a few cons that need to be fixed: - Has a few visual bugs here and there, such as the blood would fade in/out depending on how close you were or how the camera was turned. Seems to happen more on local coop. - Rest point system isn't very good. I don't know if this was a glitch or if this is some kind of timer system after you rest, but here are 3 examples. I would level up at a rest point and then go out into an area that I had cleared and all the enemies had respawned as I would have expected. Then at another point, I rested and went back out but all the enemies hadn't respawned. Lastly, at another rest point once again the enemies hadn't respawned, but I walked away to go do something in my room (since I knew for sure the area was cleared) and when I came back all the enemies were back and attacking me. - Another minor complaint related to the rest point system is how my health shots don't refill after resting like most souls-like games. I enjoy difficult games, but this is just an annoying feature that makes the game a lot harder/less fun, since there are no healing items I found.  I believe the only way to refill these was after filling a meter that gets filled from killing a certain number of enemies. - Energy/mana and health potion consumable items would be a nice addition. Maybe they were in the game, but we never encountered them. -The game needs to be clearer on when you can revive your coop partner and when reviving your coop partner will lead to your death. Since reviving requires the game to remove a large portion of your health in order to bring them back to life. Once, it gave me the option to revive my partner, but this ended up leading to my death and because I was player one, we lost and had to respawn from our last rest point. - Lastly, and probably the worst part of the game was the clunky controls and obnoxious platforming. The game feels clunky so when you are trying to jump in certain areas, don't be surprised if you fall to your death. This happened multiple times to me and my coop partner. Final score: 7/10

Review: So let me start off with the positives. This is the best depiction of Hell I've seen in a game so far. I'm also really glad they released the unrated version of the game, because this is the way the game was truly meant to look. Now for the negatives. I'm going to be honest, this game is very flawed imo and I would really only recommend it to big horror fans like myself. These are the main issues I encountered: - Controls feel very clunky  and I felt like I was often running into and getting stuck on objects. This made the game much more frustrating than it needed to be and took a lot of fun out of it. - Dialogue and voice acting (especially with the Martyrs) was bad most of the time. - Graphics were decent, but there were quite a few moments when the game and a lot of the animations looked pretty bad. - Lastly, unless you take your time collecting and exploring like I did, the game is very short and can be finished in about 4-6 hours from what I've seen. My score: .5.5/10

Review: My original review of the game was lackluster as at the time I was still fresh into my time with it, and at the time I didn't realize that the first 1/4 to 1/3 of the game was heavily front-end loaded with content. At the time, I was not bound, but somewhat obligated not to be critical of the game as I was for a few months a community moderator for the game,  I've since stepped down.  And its been several months since the game was released.  Frankly, the only word I have to describe the game is, an emotional dissapointment The world is huge, but as you exit the first 2 or 3 regions, the content of the game gets less and less.  Dont get me wrong.  When it runs good,  it looks great, its a blast to revisit the world in it's re-imagining.  And for the longest time the thing that had me most interested was the world state and the story. how things changed canonically since the last game. I wont say that I didnt enjoy it,  but I feel like the story was kind of a letdown. Very few questions were answered.  And I feel very strongly that whatever this game originally had for a script, was dramatically altered because of the invasion of Ukraine, Honestly I dont know what I was expecting but a lot of the main story felt like fan service.  It was a shame because the worldbuilding really did shine in some places. The gameplay was passable.  it was hard to get a handle on things when it was clear it was being hampered by bugs.  bugs like the A-life / Spawn circle spawning enemies behind you randomly,  AI refusing to use cover and acting recklessly,  enemies spawning exclusively with endgame gear all over the map.  When it wasn't bugging out or throwing Bullet sponges at me, it was fun. the looting mechanics and gear in general was also passable,  I appreciated much of the new toys but theres a LOT missing.  the artefacts were mostly great aside from the fact that they only spawn in preset locations just like the old games. (some areas theres static artefacts others it randomly generates one but its always the same area).  The weapons and armor were cool... the weapons were kind of a dissapointment in the modificaiton/attachment system though, I guess I thought many attachments would be modular.  especially with sights.  and I thought you'd at least be able to fetch some parts off dead stalkers sometimes.. the UI itself is more or less fine but the way the game conveys information to you is very bad.  if theres a reputation system in this game, I dont know how to read it.... It makes me wonder what the point of having all the different stalker clans is if they're all just passive to you for most of the game unless you attack them.. the older games had entire encyclopedias that would explain to you who the groups were, and they'd usually inform you too of their relations or attitude towards you. Political events in real life nearly killed the game,  multiple times over.  Its a miracle the game survived.  But unfortunatley, the honeymoon is over.  And the state of this game is not much better than Cyberpunk 2077 was in its first 6 months.  It has the potential to be great. But its going to lose considerable time to bugfixing and optimization, that will not be spent on new content. it will be worth checking back in a year or two.  Im not mad at GSC, I still like Stalker 2. Watching stalker die, return from the dead, and go through the ringer to get here again was a traumatic and emotional experience. Im glad we got it, it wasn't what I expected. But I still accept it. Until we meet again, old friend.

Review: This is my favorite CNC Game. Bar none. and I will die on that hill. Its a game from 2007,  so yes now its old. But at the time, it had very good looking graphics, the color palette made it look better than RA3 which came after it, too. The gameplay was quick yet not so fast that it felt like you needed to macro spam.  it also had that CNC Generals layer where you would build structures to unlock support and upgrade abilities.   There were 3 factions which all had a very nice, and unique lineup of units and abilities.  Every faction felt fun in its own way.  There are lots of satisfying units that mostly have clear purposes, strengths and weaknesses,  there's lots of tech structures to capture to change the dynamics of the battlefield,  they encourage base expansion with the mobile outposts.  and there's still plenty of little micro-managing things to do with infantry. CNC3 was the peak of the series as far as playing combined arms was concerned,  even squishy infantry had a role and a use.  I recall many fights that basically turned into quick paced urban battles with all sides furiously trying to occupy and flush out buildings with different troop types. production wise,  Westwood may have been gone, but its roots remained,  they were still doing the live action stuff and it honestly wasn't bad.  the worldbuilding of this game was also excellent.  They do an excellent job of convincing the player that the planet is slowly dying from the tiberium infestation, and it portrays the world as an absolute hellscape with small islands of civilization still remaining. one weird design choice that I actually adored this game for was the fact that most infantry units come in little squads.  and many units had their apperance change when you upgraded them.  it was attention to detail like that that made me adore this game.  And there's a couple of really good mods out there too. CNC3 was the peak of the series.  I loved Tiberian Sun, RA2 and Generals but Tiberium Wars and its expansion will always be my favorite.  It was one last hurrah before the series went off a cliff.

Review: Some people at Slitherin watched the 5 minute intro scene of T2, and decided lets make a game all about that. The game is overpriced for what it is.  Its a fairly low production value generic RTS that would have been commonplace back in the mid to late 2000s before the genre died. If you played a lot of Wal-Mart / Best Buy generic shovelware that filled the shelves in the 1995-2010 period.  this game will feel oddly familiar it has some advanced simulation  and tactical layers to it .  and it seems to have a lot of content as far as units are concerned with different factions.  but the skirmish and multiplayer is awful, there's only 6 maps in multiplayer, and 4 maps on skirmish.   and you can only play as 2 or 3 of the factions in skirmish.  The main antagonist faction really needs more unit variety though. Thankfully there are mods,  however most mods seem to be focused on adding units to the human factions, not the machine ones the main draw of the game is the campaign mode,  as stated theres very little production value, so expect warcract 3 style "cutscenes" with bad voice acting,  and theres one or two missions that are really poorly designed, but the rest of the gameplay loop is quite fun, it all revolves around acquiring individual units for an army, whether that be squads of infantry, or vehicles,  units that can be customized, promoted, take casualties and need new members etc.  its all handled with a fairly rudementary supply system with some strategic level resources and some tactical level ones.     Whats fun is a lot of missions you can be rewarded in-level with new squads from various factions that will join you,  and you can often find abandoned vehicles that you can fix up, and take into your army too. the skirmish mode sucks,  the campaign is pretty fun albeit with 1 or 2 stinkers of level design, and theres currentley a second dlc campaign as the machines,  supposedly there is a conquest mode coming along with a third campaign.  that DLC will be the litmus test on whether this game has any staying power past a couple campaigns... because its definetley got the guts to be a good, replayable game.

Review: Im not sure why I never reccomended this, because WOTC is a game changer. There's a few cons I'll mention them first, Most notably - to the unprepared, it DOES make the game objectively harder, regardless of which difficulty you are on, you will be occasionally encountering one of three bosses that will improve and adapt as the campaign goes on unless you can defeat them first. So some mods dont work on it. The pros far outweigh the cons though. - While difficult, your struggles against the Chosen are fun and rewarding, - 3 new Enemy types, they are a bit annoying though, - 3 resistance factions that you can recruit hero tier units from, all three of them are AWESOME. - Addition of the Lost, Zombie like mutants in some missions found in the abandoned, fallen cities of the first war. - The tactical game has several new "factions" that take their turns independently,  notably, Xcom, Advent, The Chosen, The Lost, and even friendly resistance fighters on some missions. - New Promotion system - Soldier bonding, soldiers can get a "buddy" who they gain new ability when fighting alongside - negative traits develop dynamically based on mission outcomes,  xcom soldiers may develop a fear of certain types of units, or even fear of missing shots, and panic when it happens. - Two additional music soundtracks for the game,  the original Xcom set is the best. - Probably more I forgot

Review: WRSR,  or SR for short Is what I'll call this game, because Im not typing out that long winded name.  Is what you get when you combine a train and logistics game like transport fever or OpenTTD, With a city builder.  And mix a bunch of cold war eastern brutalist architecture and a sprinkle of dirty communist pinkos in with it. In short.  It's a city builder and resource management game for control freaks.  You create a small collectivist republic, and when I say you make the country, you make pretty much everything.  This game has a frankly RIDICULOUS amount of complexity in its networks.  You have to build facilities for the people, primary industries, secondary industries, transport networks for workers, networks for off-work people, networks for resources, you even have to make networks for moving new vehicles in from the factories or importing from neighbors.... build, power, water, heating , gasoline and waste collection networks,   and everything I just mentioned probably has about 3 other support networks for each. and dont even get me started on "realistic mode". where absolutely everything has to  be built by construction crews, which use vehicles, and like 8 different construction resources. the good thing is.  you can turn off almost all of the complexity.  dont want to mess with water? turn it off,  can't figure out power, turn it off. my reccomendation is to play the game with power & gasoline, water, heat, and garbage all turned off.  turn off seasons, and  all in all, play this game in baby mode for the first couple of weeks. as you get more accustomed to how it works,  you can start turning things on one by one. to end all.  This is a "city builder"  for clinically insane people. and I am oddly quite fond of it..

Review: First and foremost, this recommendation comes with giant red flags.  This game is in early access and it is full of bugs that are likely not going to be fixed for a long time,   there are also a lot of missing features,  and some half-finished ones. The combat and some of the quest stuff works,  but playing this game is like walking through a minefield,  you never know when you're going to hit a bug that crashes it. THE GOOD - The world is familiar, yet still very fresh and new,   its quite easy to make yourself forget that this is calradia,  It reminds me a lot of both Game of Thrones, and Elder Scrolls in the different cultures and world features. - Visual package is incredible compared to the last game,  the world is pretty, character models look great,  if it wasnt for the UI you might forget this is mount and blade - The sandbox variety is HUGE.   I like how they have broken kingdoms into individual families and clans, with their own members,  this gives for a huge variety of NPCs with different quests and interactions with one another. - character design is quite good.  I like all the different themes of the 6 factions, I especially like how they did the Vlandians, Battanians and Sturgians.   I just wish they would split the empire up some and add some little differences between them, instead of just color.   I also like how every unit wears white. and their trim and clothes are tinted based on color,   No more Red coated knights in service of a yellow flag Lord.. - animaitons are sweet,  every time you kill someone it plays from a wide variety of relevant animations based on where you hit them, and what with -It's not perfect,  but the UI for giving units orders is more intuitive and user friendly now. -When they work right,  seiges are amazing.   throwing big rocks at the enemy, 10/10 - the UI managing each character showing who they are, what clan they hail from,  their friends, enemies, and family is all so much more useful... and on the topic of characters and enemies... YOU CAN EXECUTE CHARACTERS. OMG YES. - battlefields and explorable areas are huge. - reworked recruitment system,   ties into trade.  also ties into literal castle gang warfare, which is cool *Fights inside towns against gangs,   where everyone must wear civilian clothing* THE BAD - The game does have sometihng of a dynamic, radiant quest system for some NPCs,  while cool in principle,  some of the quests it sends you on are either repetitive,   impossible,  or broken. - bugged quests and worldstates,  in my game, I can't go near Vlandians because I fought them once as an independent clan,  Now as a Vassal of the Sturgians, I am forbidden to attack them,  but they can attack me, and my only choices are to surrender, or try to pay a bribe.  I cant make peace. - voice acting.  not the sound effects, but the half-measured attempt at adding voice dialogue to random NPCs,   do it for all, or none,  its weird when only a few NPCs have it. - No auto block,  even on easier difficulties the rate that the NPCs attack you is quite fast, and its easy to block with a shield but quite difficult with a spear, two hander, etc.   they really shouldn't have removed this - no cheat menu.  Yes, i said it,  I cheat.   you can turn on a few cheats,  heal yourself, teleport around, etc.  but there's no character importing,  giving yourself money,   any of that stuff.   It sucks not being able to just try the game out without grinding. especially since you run the risk of having your save corrupted. THE UGLY I have only one thing here... but this one thing is so signifigant that it dampens my entire outlook towards the game. The AI,  it HAS NOT BEEN IMPROVED AT ALL,  NPCs still swarm you, all spamming attacks, they are immune to getting their attacks tied up by neighbors,   they like to hold their shields up  and they are ALL OVER YOU. the result of many battles is , if you're on foot at least,  6 or 7 guys charging at you, all swinging their swords in a flurry.  forcing you to continously backpedal and try to swing an axe or something to the flank..  I just have to say that any game where the combat has me constantly backpedalling is dumb.  if they arent going to tune the AI to make it only focus on  like, small groups fighting other small groups.. then they need to do more work at formation fighting.  because the AI in bannerlord is just the same jumbled mess that it was in warbnad

Review: STALKER in 2020 is in a strange position,  it's supposedley getting it's long awaited sequel, but it's anyones guess if it will actually become more than vaporware, and even then, I worry that the Trog Tim Sweeney will swipe it up for a EGS exclusive. Whatever the case,  the reason I say it's a strange position in 2020, is because I was never a huge fan, nor was I ever impresed by Call of Pripyat,  it was probably the 2nd best of the original trilogy,  but what made CoP great, was the Call of Chernobyl mod was created for it, which has been the single greatest thing to come to the franchise since it's final release. CoC was a testbed for other mods,  I briefly played a mod called Call of Misery, which merged MISERY and CoC... then I played a derivative of CoM called "Last Day" however, in 2019 a derivative, of that derivative was released called Stalker: Anomaly,  and this has been the next big thing for the series in it's post-release shelf life, Stalker Anomaly runs off a custom version of the Xray Engine called "Xray Monolith" and it's a 64 bit engine,  it's very stable, I only encountered crashes when I had caused problems messing with the debug editor..   The game is an extremely well polished version of Last Day, with loads of new features, community mods merged,  and even some new quests.  the new quests are mostly a "victory tour" of the Zone, since you'll be re-doing a lot of the quests from the original trilogy in one way or another. Here's the thing about Anomaly,   and why Call of Pripyat is a funny thing to reccomend at this point. If you've never played the series before, buy Call of Pripyat,   but if you're just an old STALKER fan and you want to play in a sandbox,  there is no reason to even have CoP installed anymore.  Stalker Anomaly is 100% standalone, you dont even have to own a copy of the games to play it.  take that how you will. There are some mods out there that require CoP installed,  but bar none, Anomaly is the most complete experience you will ever get your hands on.  It's the most polished version of CoC ever made

Review: Kenshi is kind of like a Rust server,  except all the bullets were used up Lots of naked people, Lots of savagery, and lots of slavery. Kenshi has actually been one of my most beloved indie games I've ever picked up,  it took a long while to really learn and understand both the game setting, and the game mechanics.  because at first glance I wouldn't have picked this up if I hadn't seen some reviews showing it for what it is. Kenshi is a sandbox RPG, both figurative and literally (you're gonna see a lot of sand). The goal of Kenshi is to SURVIVE.  *Seriously, something as trivial as being fed is actually a challenge, this is an extremely hostile, desolate and deadly world I'm not an expert on the game's lore. but it seems to me that it takes place in a world that was previously part of a highly advanced empire, possibly even space faring... but none of that matters now.  Because it's been thousands of years since then.   Kenshi is a post apocalypse game on an alien planet where all of the bullets dried up centuries ago.   Reverting back to a dark age where everything is made out of crude iron and steel. and the only weapons are swords, clubs and crossbows. The world is VAST, and it is BRUTAL. Comprised of 30-40 'regions" varying in size, even the smallest take upwards of 10 minutes to cross.  and you'll have to contend with hostile wildlife, hostile NPC groups ranging everything from anorexic starving beggars to skin bandit robots, cannibals, racist reilgious zealots and Slaving Imperial Samurai,   And Kenshi is the very definition of a grind.  there roughly 30 weapon proficiencies, physical attributes, combat skills and trades/professions to level up,  and you have to GRIND to get them to be even on par with mid tier enemies. Kenshi is extremely moddable though,  I'm someone who shamelessly cheats and mods my games for personal enjoyment,  and you have all the tools you need to give yourself a head start in any way imaginable. at this point I should also mention that Kenshi is not an RPG played from a single character experience *You could do that, though. nothing says you cant*. you can control up to 50 characters in real time,  all over the world.  *up to 256 with mods*.  And with controlling so many characters, you can do  the same as you did with 1, which is to say, almost anything You can hunt bounties,  scavenge and sell loot, rescue slaves *or take them!*.  and the best part of it all, you can build your own empire.  you can build structures in almost any part of the map, you'll start off with only having access to  small shacks and junk tier tech.  But with research, good economic planning, and a bit of luck, you can eventually grow your faction to self sufficiency. grow your own food, make your own clothing, armor and weapons.  build caravans and trade off excess goods and raw materials.  buy blueprints for bigger and better stuff. etc.  the game has a pretty basic, but robust economy,  there is a resource chain for almost everything,  spare the ultra rare pre-collapse tech, which must be found unless you're playing a *cheated* god character,  building your own faction is the only way to make an impact on the world.  There are probably 50 some factions *many of which are just different versions of bandits and cannibals,  but you get the idea*... and you maintain relations with all of them.  kill off,  or turn in certain characters for bounties... and you'll cause irreversable changes in the world... manage to capture the leader of the holy nation and trek across the wasteland to turn him in to the United Cities?... you'll see a large portion of the world fall into chaos as several groups of cannibals and bandits now flood the plains the Holy Nation used to secure,  their very cities collapse from the power vaccum. I could go on and on about this game.  All I have to say is, yes it's an acquired taste, but it's an excellent game!

There is no excuse for the amount of hacking that goes on in a game of this size - Free roam is a toxic swamp of internet tough guys, racists, griefers, hackers, tryhards, screamers and squeakers. Review: I'm not sure why I didn't have a review of this already. Because I really enjoyed it, and had a lot of hours in it. RWR is hard to categorize.  If I were to slap labels on it for what it's similar to... It reminds me a lot of the old 3D0 Army Men games,  mixed in with some grand battle mechanics like you'd see in a game like dynasty warriors.  It also has several levels that are clearly copied from Battlefield 2. It's a third person / top down shooting game where you play the role of a grunt in one of the three competing armies, brown, gray and green.   Dozens to hundreds of AI soldiers will follow squad leaders around the map, trying to capture the bases and complete side objectives... and You start off with nothing but a rifle, grenades and your thumb up your butt, and you have to shoot, stab and explode enough soldiers to get a promotion to be eligible to use better gear... The combat system is very basic,  you can run, walk, stand crouch and crawl.  there is a somewhat functional cover system,   and the damage system is actually pretty clever. Rather than health points,  every bullet that hits you rolls a RNG for a chance to kill, based on the weapon it's higher or lower.   Starting weapons on each faction have slightly different stats too. So there's something of an identity,  not just red vs blue teams...   vehicles also follow the same principle as far as stats.  but they do use HP.  There will also be troops running around in varying levels of body armor who will be harder to kill...  as well as veteran and elite boss units running around carrying rare weapons.  you'll even get a chance to capture enemy weapons or intel briefcases, and bring them back to base to permanetley add them to your own armory. RWR isn't a very popular game anymore, at the time of writing this there's often less than 50 people playing it.  the singleplayer is good, you can play a quick match in a 2 way, or 3 way battle,  with several sliders for gameplay options.  you can also play campaign, where you side with one army, and fight to take over all of the maps in the world, progessing from grunt to general along the way. There's also plenty of PVP, and PVE potential in this game. It's currentley $5 as of writing,  I say it's still worth full price. It's also one of the few games I've published mods for, due to its simple voxel model nature. Highly reccomended for a casual war game

Men of War is one of those games from Eastern Europe.  And like Stalker and Metro 2033, this game is surprisingly good for being developed by a small Ukrainian based company. This is a really strange RTS/RPGS/FPS Hybrid.  It's mainly a stragety game but it involves RPG elements like inventory management and such, theres also some features in there to take control of individual untis like an action game. The editor is fairly easy to use and the battles are extremley realistic, but fun at the same time.  If you can get used to the controls and how everything works, I highly reccommend tihs game to pretty much anyone who enjoys any kind of combat game.
